With it being that the markets around the world create opportunities in other segments, we recognized Food early on as a diversification opportunity, started with our interesting acquisition in the '80s, where you have paying the dri-loc absorbent pads for meat trays, which really gave us a flavor of what happened in the Food business. Followed it up in the '90s with the acquisition of Trigon, which got us into the protein packaging business primarily in Asia Pacific and Europe, followed with Cryovac in 1998. And as we look for further end-market opportunities, again using core technologies and core manufacturing capabilities, we see kind of the diversification into the Medical business as being another logical step for a couple of reasons. One, being the aging population and the increase in demand for healthcare by older populations, and two, the more emphasis on healthcare in the emerging markets. So we see that as a growth opportunity. And the opportunity has really been focused from our core competencies and basically, polymer science and extrusion and the manufacturing. We may have a lot of end markets, but a lot of the inputs and processes are similar. We continue to look about whether there's something else beyond Industrial, Food and Medical. But right now, we're focusing on the portfolio we have, but thanks for asking the question. So I would like to thank everyone for your participation for the call today. As we continue to perform through the second quarter, we'll remain optimistic that the modest recovery we saw last quarter will continue to provide growth opportunities for us in the year ahead. This recovery, combined with our growth strategies, our lead and expensive international network, ongoing innovations and expanding customer relationships position us to accelerate our growth rates, expand margins and continue to deliver measurable value for our customers and stockholders. And again, I would like to say I'm really proud to be a Sealed Air shareholder, and thank you for taking the time to listen to us today.

componenttext:
Thank you, Amanda, and good morning, everyone. During today's call, I will be highlighting our business performance for the second quarter, and Dave will discuss details of our financial results. After Dave's remarks, we will take your questions both from the phone lines and via text on our webcast. I understand that this morning is a busy morning for earnings releases, so we'll try to move along very smartly.
Yesterday evening, we reported a 15% increase on our second quarter earnings per share of $0.38. Excluding $0.03 related to foreign currency exchange gains from our Venezuelan subsidiary in 2010 and a $0.01 impact from GMS in 2009, we reported a 3% increase on our adjusted EPS to $0.35 per share in the quarter.
As a reminder, we have elected to exclude any foreign currency translation, gains or losses, from Venezuela in 2010 due to the significant currency fluctuations in that country. We did, however, have a $0.02 foreign exchange loss in the quarter, which is reported in other income. And excluding that item, which records we're responsible for, on an operating income basis, we're essentially in the line with the consensus of last year estimates for the second quarter.
Sales increased 6% to $1.1 billion, reflecting approximately 5% higher volume and 3% favorable foreign exchange, which were partially offset by 1% lower price mix.
Our Protective Packaging segment stood out in the quarter with strong 12% volume growth. While volume growth in our Food Packaging segment was modest in the quarter, it exceeded customer production volumes during the same period.
Total company price mix remained below last year's level, but we did see marked improvement in the second quarter as we started to see the benefits of our April pricing actions later in the quarter. Although been official, the price increases did not offset the surge in resin costs that we experienced in the quarter when resin prices peaked in the month of April in most regions.
In light of these factors, our business demonstrated solid growth in the second quarter in several areas. First, our industrial packaging business volume growth was stronger than expected and above normal seasonal trends. Looking at protective packaging, North American volumes increased 10% and Europe achieved a solid 11% volume growth. We expected this level of growth to moderate slightly in the second half of the year, primarily due to the year-over-year comparisons.
Additionally, we are seeing strong reception of new solutions and technologies like our CT-301 Shrink Film where our new proprietary technology is extending our range of offerings and bringing us new customers. We will be reinforcing this product line with two additional launches later this year. So we're very excited about the growth prospects in shrink films and where we can extend this exciting new technology across our broader product portfolio.
We have observed significant growth in equipment demand with a 36% sales increase in equipment, which includes a 3% favorable impact from foreign exchange. This order rate currently exceeds production rates, reflecting solid backlogs going into the third quarter. Additionally, orders appear to largely reflect new installations versus replacements, which suggest that these equipment sales will lead to future incremental material sales opportunities.
Developing regions grew in the quarter, both on a year-over-year and the sequential basis. Our China sales were a little weaker, which you may have seen in our financials under the Asia Pacific region, but this was expected due to pre-buying in our medical business in the first quarter, as customers built inventory ahead of our formulation license renewal.
Overall, we saw solid growth throughout the quarter in countries like Mexico, Brazil and Southeast Asia, as our businesses did not see any economic weakness or slowdown in these economies. We believe that this growth remains on track through the balance of the year.
Europe has been a topic of much interest in the last few months, and I have to say that we are encouraged by the solid 5% volume growth rate in the region, which was largely driven by our industrial packaging business, but also by a 3% volume growth rate in food packaging.
So we believe we have turned the corner in the second quarter and our daily sales reports through late July support this view and as we are already saying, improved food volumes and ongoing growth in industrials and in the developing regions. We continue to be excited about the second half of the year and expect to accelerate sales and earnings going forward.
Before we discuss our earnings guidance, I'd like to highlight a few key points on each of our primary business segments. As I mentioned earlier, the food packaging business exceeded customer production rates with modest growth in the quarter in the first half of the year.
Looking ahead, the full year prospects look solid, with industry data suggesting North America beef production up 4% to 5% in the second half of the year. This compares to a minus 1% to minus 4% customer production rates in the first half of the year. Additionally, contract price adjustments to recover higher resin costs go into effect in the third quarter. Thus our second quarter price remained unfavorable on a year-over-year basis.
We excelled in two key areas in the quarter. First, equipment sales were up over 39%, which includes a 4% favorable impact from foreign exchange; and secondly, 8% volume growth in Latin America where our team did a solid job throughout the quarter by expanding the presence of our product lines in this important region.
Looking at developing regions, the business saw no slowdown in economies like Brazil, Mexico and China related to food packaging demand, and we anticipate that trend going forward. So looking ahead, a pickup in customer production volumes, new customer contracts, incremental price, and continued success in shifting pilot projects into commercial sales around our recently launched solutions are expected to bring mid to upper single digit percent constant dollar sales growth in the second half versus the prior year.
The food solutions business continued to experience improvement in the quarter, with a 1% volume increase, with the strongest demand occurring in June and in the Asia-Pacific and European regions. We were pleased to see that European performance improved both year-over-year and sequentially with a 4% sales increase over the first quarter.
The primary drivers behind the pickup in sales in Europe are from solid volume growth in our ready meals portfolio related largely to pizza and to equipment demand. Although European case ready sales were not ahead of last year, the region did see improved demand in the portfolio due to an expanded development program for whole chickens in the Middle East, and ongoing market growth in our Mirabella and Darfresh formats.
Also in the quarter, we saw signs of consumers starting to return to more convenience oriented and higher-priced point products at retail. This reinforced our view that the food industry is starting its slow recovery process.
Looking closely at the two primary product portfolios, case-ready and vertical pouch packaging, first, case-ready sales decreased by 1%, which included a 1% unfavorable impact from foreign exchange. However, we did see an 8% sales increase in case-ready in North America, and over a 20% increase in case-ready in Latin America, as our market programs continued to expand the products' presence in these parts of the world.
A great example of this type of growth is in the Americas, where in Canada, we have just launched case-ready with two large retailers, one of which is a division of a leading multinational retailer. This growth in the Americas was offset by weakness in Europe, which I previously indicated.
Number two, vertical pouch packaging showed the greatest growth this quarter in this segment as sales increased 5% which included a 1% unfavorable impact from foreign exchange. Growth was strongest in North America and the Asia-Pacific region, where sales increased by over 30%.
Looking ahead to the second half, we expect this segment to see similar constant dollar sales growth as our food packaging business. Improving retail conditions, combined with incremental price from both second quarter and early third quarter increases will help drive top-line growth, so also will ongoing successful market growth of our case-ready products in developing markets like Russia and the successful transition of pilot projects into commercial sales.
As you saw in our financials, protective packaging segment was a standout segment this quarter, as the business drove over two-thirds of our volume growth. When looking at the 12% volume growth versus the prior year, I am pleased to report that volumes are up at all regions of the world, including the 10% and 11% increases in North America and Europe, which I discussed earlier.
I also would like to point out that the segment saw approximately 20% growth in Latin America and in Asia-Pacific region, as the business continued to develop new customer relationships. Interesting, European growth was broader than most would have expected, including growth in countries like Portugal and Spain.
Naturally, the strongest sales increase was achieved in Northern Europe, Scandinavia, France and Germany, where the industrial output remained solid. Contributing to the growth was our very successful new product programs, which are getting strong reception and selling above both planned and prior year rates.
These new products include our Instapak complete and (Fastfill) packaging solutions. Additionally, we have achieved strong growth in proprietary solutions such as our traditional Instapak foam-in-place product and in Korrvu suspension packaging.
Looking ahead to the second half of the year, we're expecting constant dollar sales growth in the high single digits as we see ongoing benefits from the economy, new solution sales, and both our April price actions and the European price announcement issued this month.
To wrap up before I hand the call to Dave, I would like to reaffirm our full year EPS guidance which is a $1.48 to $1.68 on a reported basis, or $1.50 to $1.70 if adjusted to exclude a $0.02 charge related to the GMS program.
As I stated earlier in the call, the first half year surge in raw materials and slower food customer production volume are both abating, and second half 2010 results are expected to outperform our first half performance. This positions us to achieve a full year EPS within the mid range of our earnings guidance.
As I mentioned, ongoing modest improvements in the economy, combined with accelerated constant dollar sales from product adoptions and the benefits of our pricing actions will be the key drivers to this growth.
Additionally, we assume foreign exchange to be a net positive by 1% to 2% for the full year. We also see additional benefits from our steadfast commitment to innovation throughout the economic downturn. During this time, we have been developing a strong pipeline of proprietary technologies and applications that have been in development with customers for several quarters now.
We expect to start commercializing many of these in late 2010, as several projects reach market stage and are positioned to generate value for our business.
At this point, I am going to turn the call over to Dave to review some additional details on our financial performance and our liquidity.

componenttext:
Thank you, Bill. As presented in the financial statements that accompanied our release, sales were $1.089 billion for the quarter. Moving down to P&L, gross profit for the quarter increased 4% or $12 million to $301 million. Excluding favorable currency translation of $7 million, gross profit would have been $5 million higher than 2009.
Gross profit growth was largely driven by volume growth in the industrial businesses, which Bill previously touched upon. Also contributing to our higher gross profit were benefits realized from our supply chain productivity improvements and from the benefits of producing products in our new, low-cost facilities in developing regions.
These benefits were partially offset by approximately $45 million of increased resin cost and $13 million of unfavorable price mix compared to last year. Second quarter marketing, administrative and developmental expenses increased 1% or $2 million to $172 million. Excluding unfavorable foreign currency translation of $3 million, these expenses would have remained flat.
The higher sales volumes that we achieved in the quarter required higher sales and marketing support costs, which were offset by lower provisions for variable incentive compensation expenses, mainly due to revenue levels in our food businesses and the impact of higher resin cost. We are still estimating operating expenses to be 16% to 17% of net sales for the full year, in line with our guidance at the beginning of the year.
Operating profit was $129 million, or 11.9% of revenue. After adjusting for $4 million of favorable foreign currency translation, operating profit would have been $7 million higher than 2009. Our industrial businesses reported a combined 52% increase in operating profit as compared to last year, which was offset by a combined 5% decline in operating profit in our two food businesses.
We expect the operating profits of our food businesses to improve in the third quarter, as we realized benefits from our previously announced pricing actions in contract pricing adjustments, as well as the volume opportunities that Bill mentioned.
Interest expense increased by $3 million in the second quarter of 2010 compared to 2009, reflecting additional interest of $7 million on the 7-7/8% notes issued in June of last year, partially offset by a reduction of $4 million resulting from the redemption of the 3% convertible notes in July of last year.
As mentioned in our press release, we recognized $7 million of foreign currency exchange gains related to our subsidiary in Venezuela. Due to the unpredictable foreign currency environment in Venezuela, with the resulting (Bolivar) fluctuations in exchange rates, we are excluding any gains or losses we may recognize related to these changes in exchange rates from our adjusted earnings per share. While this exchange gain is sizeable, our Venezuelan subsidiary represents less than 1% of our consolidated revenues and our consolidated assets.
Other expense was $3 million in the second quarter. This amount includes net foreign currency exchange losses, primarily relating to an inter-company loan we are in the process of paying off.
I'll now conclude with some key cash flow and balance sheet items. Cash and cash equivalents increased $36 million in the second quarter to $663 million at June 30. During the quarter, we paid dividends of $19 million and invested $11 million in our previously announced new facility in Brazil designed for expanded capacity.
In the quarter, we also used $8 million to complete a small bolt-on acquisition which provides us with the opportunity to develop a new unique technology platform, offering both cost savings and revenue growth opportunities for existing and new proprietary applications.
As this is a technology investment, we anticipate an ongoing development phase in 2010 and expect the initial commercialization of products in 2011.
Our receivables remained flat from March 31, 2010 on a reported U.S. dollar basis. Excluding foreign currency translation of $22 million which reflects the declining euro in the period, our receivables increased $23 million, in line with our increases in sales volume.
Inventory investment increased $10 million during the quarter. Excluding foreign currency translation of $13 million, also mainly due to the weakening euro, inventories increased $23 million. At June 30, inventory levels were higher in North America and Europe, mainly in our food businesses, reflecting peak resin costs in April and a buildup of inventories in anticipation of increased sales volumes from normal seasonality in these businesses.
Debt, net of cash, and cash equivalents at June 30 was $921 million, down $33 million from March 31 of this year. Also at June 30, we had no amounts outstanding under our global or European credit facilities, or our accounts receivable securitization program. Our available committed borrowing capacity was $750 million at June 30 of 2010.
As shown in the supplemental information with the financial statements, we generated $181 million of free cash flow in the first six months of 2010. Cash flow from operating results was comparable to last year, but working capital swung to usage from the source last year as we responded to the recovery of the global economy.
We continue to expect free cash flow to exceed $300 million in 2010. And as we noted in our press release this morning, we did announce a dividend increase that is going to be a modest additional payout that will not in any way affect our ability to exceed the free cash flow targets of $300 million.
Capital investment in the first six months was $4 million lower than 2009 as work is completed on three new plants we opened in developing regions as part of our GMS program.
Our total year capital investment for 2010 is still expected to be in the range of $80 million to $100 million to be used for a combination of maintenance and growth projects. This range includes our recent investment in Brazil, and is consistent with our annual investment before commencing our GMS projects in 2006.
Finally, our current available liquidity and our projected free cash flow position us to fund both our day-to-day operations and the W.R. Grace settlement, should it become payable within the next 12 months.
Now I'll turn the call back to Bill and to your questions.

On the pricing catch-up, we will be there in the second half of the year, most likely solidly there in the fourth quarter. So if the curve is run as they've run in the past, as that price level continues into the first half of next year, we do stand to recover the $100 million-plus of higher resin costs that we're looking at in 2010 compared to last year.
With regard to the fall off in pricing, clearly some of the commodity resins are off of their April peaks. But if you look at a curve for the last 12 months to 18 months, even at the end of June and going into July, resin pricing is still significantly higher than it was at the beginning of the year and significantly higher than it was a year ago. So the relief is welcome, but it's hardly a rollback to 2009 levels.

What I would add to Dave's comment which I think may be helpful for you to understand how we look at resin and how maybe you factor it in your own outlook is remember that we buy probably half our resin outside the United States. And again, half the resin is commodity and half is not.
And in Europe, actually there is an increase in resin prices, which is why during my comment I mentioned that we were having a price increase in the protective business in Europe in July, because although resin has declined in the U.S. in May and June, it actually has gone up in Europe, so that you need to be price-sensitive when you're looking at the outlook for Sealed Air to factor in the half our resin is outside the U.S. and follows a different curve. Eventually they average out, but they do have different leads and lags and then the fact that only half of it responses to the commodity curve.

Case-ready, we haven't seen any new competition. We heard a lot about it for a few years, but we haven't seen any. I think it's seven formats of case-ready, and we look at it depending on the customer, the market and the consumer interest. We can sort of provide a variety of case-ready alternatives.

But on a global basis, case-ready numbers are still positive. We do believe our seven offerings, plus two or three we have in the lab, will continue to give customers the most choice, the most opportunity and we think the best combined offering you can get in the marketplace.

I'd like to think that Europe is turning back up, but I also mentioned we've got three groups of countries in Europe and the business breaks up that way. Group one, which for most of our businesses are still slow, still very smudge in the recession or final stages of it, and that's the Spain, Greece and the U.K. Then you've got group two where we are seeing an improvement and where France and Italy we're up high single digits. And I think those are fair amount export-driven if you look at German and Scandinavian economies, and I think they have also been more frugal in terms of their financial policies.
